awd_titl_txt: Tectonic Escape of the Panama Microplate?  Kinematics Along the Western Boundary, Costa Rica
awd_abstract_narration: Plate tectonics provides a conceptual framework for                        placing a number of structural features in rather specific                      tectonic settings, however the effects of second-order                          variations are not well constrained.  This project will                         examine the possible effects of aseismic ridge subduction on                    an active system of faults in Panama.  Presently, two                           hypotheses are viable- the deformation is due to "escape                        tectonics" resulting in Cocos Ridge penetration or the                          deformation is due simply to the west end of the Panama                         microplate, unrelated to the Cocos Ridge.  These models will                    be tested by measuring displacements of Quaternary terraces                     and volcanic flows, structural studies of faults, and                           analysis of focal plane earthquake mechanisms.  Each model                      predicts different spatial distributions of faults,                             different timing and styles of deformation.  Results will                       help understand microplate boundaries and interactions in                       the western Caribbean/Central America area and are expected                     to apply to microplate tectonics in other areas.
